title: 108_s2932
content: The Act titled the "Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Act of 2004" honors Senator Hatfield and Congresswoman Furse for their work in strengthening tribal self-governance and advocating for Native American rights. The Act establishes programs to promote excellence in tribal government. The Act defines key terms such as Board, eligible individual, Foundation, Fund, Institute, institution of higher education, and State. The Act lists various entities including states, territories, and islands such as American Samoa, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the United States Virgin Islands. Establishment of the Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation. The Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation is established as an independent entity in the Executive branch. It is supervised by a Board of Trustees consisting of 12 members appointed by the President and approved by the Senate. The Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation is overseen by a Board of Trustees with 5 appointed individuals, including tribal leaders and government officials. Trustees serve 6-year terms, with specific roles designated for the Secretary of the Interior, Secretary of Education, and the president of Portland State University. The president of Portland State University serves as a nonvoting member and cannot be the Chairperson. The Board of Trustees for the Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation consists of 5 appointed individuals serving 6-year terms. Trustees are designated by the President and serve varying term lengths based on their appointment under different subsections. Vacancies are filled by trustees serving the remainder of the predecessor's term. The Foundation's Board of Trustees consists of appointed individuals serving 6-year terms. Trustees serve without pay but are reimbursed for expenses. The Foundation is located in Portland, Oregon. An Executive Director, appointed by the Board, oversees the Foundation's functions and is compensated at a specified rate. The Executive Director, appointed by the Board of Trustees, is compensated at a specified rate according to the Executive Schedule under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. The Foundation aims to train Native American and Alaska Native tribal council members in self-government, promote understanding of tribal self-government in the US, address critical issues facing tribal governments, conduct tribal governance research, and provide educational outreach on tribal self-government. The Foundation, in consultation with the Institute, may conduct programs and award scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants for study in tribal governance. It may also organize national competitions to select recipients. The Foundation, in consultation with the Institute, may conduct programs and award scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants for study in tribal governance. Recipients of scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants under this Act shall be known as "Elizabeth Furse Scholars". The Foundation may award scholarships to undergraduate students intending to pursue careers related to tribal governance and Native American and Alaska Native undergraduate students intending to pursue careers in tribal public policy. Scholarship recipients must maintain satisfactory proficiency, devote full time to study or research, and not engage in gainful employment other than approved by the Foundation. The Foundation may require reports from scholarship recipients. The Foundation may require reports from eligible individuals awarded scholarships under this Act, accompanied by a certificate of satisfactory progress. Fellowships may be awarded to outstanding graduate students in fields related to tribal governance, tribal public policy, law, or medicine. The Foundation awards internships and grants to individuals for participating in various agencies and organizations related to tribal governance, public health, and public policy. Additionally, the Foundation assists in coordinating development efforts. The Foundation assists in coordinating the development of a tribal governance research program at the Institute. It determines program priorities and allocates funds, with specific requirements for the use of funds for different programs at specified percentages. The Foundation allocates funds for tribal governance research programs at the Institute, with specific requirements for fund usage and limitations on administrative expenses. SEC. 7. ESTABLISHMENT OF MARK O. HATFIELD-ELIZABETH FURSE SCHOLARSHIP AND EXCELLENCE IN TRIBAL GOVERNANCE TRUST FUND. A trust fund named the "Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, to be managed by the Foundation and invested in public debt securities. SEC. 8. EXPENDITURES AND AUDIT OF TRUST FUND. The Foundation will use interest and earnings from the Fund to carry out the Act. The Government Accountability Office can audit the Foundation and the Institute's activities under the Act. Access to all relevant documents is granted for the audit. Administrative provisions are outlined in Section 9. The Foundation is authorized to appoint personnel, procure services of experts, promulgate regulations, and accept gifts to support its work. The Foundation is authorized to appoint personnel, procure services of experts, accept gifts, and make necessary expenditures to carry out its work. It can also accept voluntary personnel and reimburse them for travel expenses, enter into contracts without performance bond, and make other necessary expenditures. Authorization of appropriations to the Fund is set at $50,000,000.
